results.title: Boomerang (A)
results.brief_description: Aborigine, Jackson Jacob (Thunalgunaldin) demonstrates and explains how a returning boomerang is made. Opens with a legend describing the origin of the boomerang.

results.title: Boomer
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Radford, Michael Scott and Dale Phillips
results.brief_description: For some of us home and work are not in the same place. Well paid as a boiler-maker, Gary Honig must often leave home to exercise his highly specialised skill. Sometimes, his wife and two daughters accompany him in their trailer but more often they remain behind in their home in Stony Creek, Alberta. The film describes how one family copes, combining family life, and work in the increasingly industrialised West.

results.title: Boomalli: five Koorie artists
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Paul Humfress and Michael Riley
results.brief_description: Boomalli is an artists’ co-operative - a collection of photographers, painters, sculptors, designers and filmmakers, who are urban Aboriginal or Koorie artists. The work presented ranges from that of fashion designer Bronwyn Bancroft, the sand sculpture of Fiona Foley, Tracey Moffatt’s film, “Nice coloured girls” and the paintings of Raymond Meeks and Jeffrey Samuals. This visually rich and inspiring film is about their work. Their achievements speak for themselves.

results.title: Boom (Canada's Expo 67)
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Alain Grothe
results.brief_description: Shows the rapid expansion of Montreal in the last few years due to the building of Expo 67 in that city. Views of the city are combined with a coverage of the Expo site in the process of construction. Narrated by Lorne Greene.

results.title: Boolean procedure
results.creator_credit: Muscle Films, Michael Coulson and Nicola Bruce
results.brief_description: The introduction of Micro-technology has brought about change and crisis, which will alter our value systems and the way we spend our time. Through a bizarre mutation of live action and exciting graphic animation, the film makes us passengers in a world of artificial voices, plastic sound and faceless people. This film was shown at the Melbourne Film Festival, 1981.

results.title: Books go walkabout
results.brief_description: The State Library Bookmobile. The librarian in charge and the driver bring a wide variety of books to places without a permanent library building: old people’s homes; small country schools and townships; isolated farms. Shows the fittings of the travelling library, the librarian answering queries and bringing batches of books specially requested for particular purposes.

results.title: Books for Beaver River
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Guy Glover and Donald Ginsberg
results.brief_description: It took a boy with his eyes on the stars to show that even the best town is a poor town when it has no place for books. Beaver River, a farming community in north central Saskatchewan, has paved roads, a new school, a curling rink, and many television sets, but no place where a boy could find a book about the stars. In this film Beaver River gets its own library and, in the process, illustrates Saskatchewan’s regional library system which provides book loans at minimum costs to municipality and province. This film is historically good for the pictorial/architecture/general life style of such a country town of it’s time.

results.title: Books for all
results.brief_description: Shows the eagerness of third world people to learn reading and writing. Presents the progress, with the assistance of UNESCO, of the Delhi Free Library, showing its children’s story hour, its veranda ‘reading room’, its touring book van, and other facilities. Urges that all people should consider the illiteracy of half the world’s population their problem.

results.title: Books and people: the wealth within
results.brief_description: States that education is a continuing process which does not end when school studies are completed. The ways in which the modern public library serves this purpose and meets practical needs in the community are illustrated. The film describes how the Alabama library extension agency operates and how it helps local communities in establishing and strengthening county libraries. Various forms of library services designed to meet special needs in the community are described. These include the use of bookmobiles to bring books, recorded music, and films to outlying rural communities.
